I think there's been a move of big tech
to both want the powers of government,
but also to want money from government.

The concentration of government
and tech power together

is a serious threat
to human liberty.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Tim, thank you so much for being
here with Harvard Business School's

Institute for Business
in Global Society today.
Pleasure.

So we're pretty excited
to see you on stage today,

and you're going to be addressing the very
timely question of, is big tech too big?

So what's your
answer going to be?
I think the answer is yes.

I think that tech has gone from an industry
that was incredibly vibrant, competitive,

you know, little guys trying
to start a new company;

to a bunch of big, hulking 
juggernauts that are too reliant

on government funding and 
becoming a danger to human liberty.

So I think the answer
is obviously yes.

The American public might
be surprised to hear you say

that they're relying
on government funding.
Tell us about that.

Well, I think 
this is kind of new.

You know, Silicon Valley for
a long time had this view that

we're separate from government,
we don't particularly need anything

from government, we try 
and stay away from it.

I think that the trend has been
towards an embrace of government.

Most obvious thing is Elon Musk
actually being in government.

But more generally, a tend towards 
seeking out military funding,

defense contracting,
other government contracts.

I think there's been a move of big tech
to both want the powers of government,
but also to want money from government,

and I think it's a very negative
tendency in Silicon Valley's history.

So what is your big concern with Elon
Musk in the White House right now?

I mean, I don't 
know where you start.

But you know, it's not normal to
have a businessman ordering around

members of the Cabinet, like 
General Zod from Superman II,
or something like that.

It's not normal for him, for a person
who's not actually been Senate confirmed,

to have this kind of authority
over what's going on.
There's all kinds of problems.

But I think the
problems go both ways,

because I think it's also a
problem for Silicon Valley.

You know, I think Silicon Valley
is in danger of becoming more like

aerospace or automotive, you
know, these big old industries

or like the defense
industrial complex,

where they're just too
reliant on government,

too big, too protected
from competition.

What are your biggest worries about
the future of technology right now?
I think that it is concentration.

The concentration of government
and tech power together

is a serious threat
to human liberty.

And what I mean by that,
if you imagine a future where

not only is everything known about you,
which already is partially our case,

but then the government
knows everything, too.

You know, like in China, it uses whatever
technological measures are possible

to try and control our behavior or
move people up or move people down.

I just think we are in actual
danger of a dystopian future,

and I guess that's
what I'm worried about.

You've also spoken about
child privacy protection.
Can you tell us about that?

I and most Americans think that
children need to be better protected
online, on the internet.

Many parents like me don't let
their children use many devices,

but even when they do, it seems 
to me very common sense that

their privacy should be more
strongly protected than it is.

For whatever reasons, tech 
companies don't want to do it,

and Congress won't pass any laws
to protect children's privacy

other than the basic
laws they have.

So it seems like the most
obvious thing in the world

that we should be better
protecting children online,

but somehow as a country,
we're unable to do it.

And you're talking
across administrations.
Yes, that's right.

When I was in the White House, we fought
hard to try to get privacy laws passed,
and we just couldn't do it.

They wouldn't vote on it. We 
just couldn't get bills passed.
Can you share insights as to why?
Because big tech was opposed.
I think that's a one-line answer.

There's a lot of complicated excuses,
but I think when it comes down to it,

big tech was opposed and
didn't want these laws to pass.

What do you say to critics who
argue that American tech dominance

is a strategic asset, and that
we're weakening it with regulation?

I agree the American tech
dominance is an asset.

I think the way you keep
your tech industry strong

is you force them to compete, and 
you don't let them be monopolists.

Monopolies have a historic
tendency to be fat and lazy.

And I think even though American tech
companies seem pretty great right now,

they are big and now
increasingly old companies.

And I think if we want to continue our
tech dominance, we have to completely

keep their feet to the fire and force
them to compete in the marketplace.

Let's talk about AI. Microsoft 
and OpenAI now dominate.

Are AI monopolies different
from traditional monopolies?

I think what we want, so yes, first of
all, AI being able to replicate humans

has particular power, and I think is a
particular challenge to human autonomy.

So there's that. The idea 
of us being displaced.

But I also think what we want is we
don't want AI, which is new technology,

just to be an extension
of the old monopolies:
Google, Microsoft, and so forth.

AI should be its own industry, the 
same way tech was its own industry.

I mean, the internet industry
challenged the phone companies,

challenged the old computer
companies like IBM.

AI, I think,
OpenAI is a challenger,

but we want that industry to challenge,
not strengthen tech monopoly.

What is your advice for business leaders
now, as they contemplate integrating AI?

What are the questions
they should be asking?

I think they would want to think hard about
what kind of dependence they're gaining.

A danger for any business is becoming
too dependent on somebody else.

The question is, you know, do you become
dependent on a business at point one,

such that your margins are totally
subject to their control later on?

I think this has been a constant
challenge for those who have

dealt with the tech industry, is at
 first it seems like this great deal.

You know, you get stuff for free, or 
you're an Amazon seller kind of stuff.

But later on, you find out that
maybe you've given up too much.

So any business that's sort of jumping
into AI and wanting to implement AI,

I think needs to be very careful
to make sure they actually control
their own business in the future.

What will you be watching
as you monitor what the

Trump administration does when
it comes to big tech regulation?

The big question is whether,
JD Vance was a critic of big tech,

a believer that the tech
industry has become too powerful.

Obviously, you have Elon Musk
joining the administration
and doing all kinds of things.

The real question is whether
this is a JD Vance White House,

or whether this is an Elon
Musk White House, you know,

and what side Trump takes
on all these things.

I think that is the thing I'd be
watching for the future of big tech.

A year ago, you'd said in a fireside
chat that if the government loses

any antitrust cases, then we'd enter
an era of long term monopolization,

where big tech, three, four,
five companies are entrenched.

How close are we to that scenario?
And what does that mean for society?

Well, honestly, the government
hasn't lost any antitrust cases yet,
so we don't know.
But I hold by that prediction,

I think that it's important for
industries to reinvigorate themselves.

So the government winning these
antitrust cases is important, I think,

to the rebirth and the constant
rejuvenation of the tech industry.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
